questions.question_text: What is the main purpose of the Mac Sensor report?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Answer B
B. To provide a summary view of selected activities on Mac hosts

choices.D: To provide a dashboard for Mac related detections
choices.B: To provide a summary view of selected activities on Mac hosts
choices.A: To identify endpoints that are in Reduced Functionality Mode
choices.C: To provide vulnerability assessment for Mac Operating Systems

questions.question_text: Where would an analyst find information about shells spawned by root, Kernel Module loads, and wget/curl usage?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
"...by root..." gave this away...

Selected Answer: B
B. Linux Sensor report

Selected Answer: D
Answer D
D. The Mac Sensor report provides a comprehensive view of activities occurring on Mac hosts, including items of interest that may be hunting or investigation leads

Selected Answer: D
D Is the correct answer

Selected Answer: D
The Mac Sensor report provides a
comprehensive view of activities occurring on Mac hosts, including items of interest that may be
hunting or investigation leads.

choices.D: The Mac Sensor report provides a comprehensive view of activities occurring on Mac hosts, including items of interest that may be hunting or investigation leads
choices.B: The Mac Sensor report provides a detection focused view of known malicious activities occurring on Mac hosts, including machine-learning and indicator-based detections
choices.A: The Mac Sensor report displays a listing of all Mac hosts without a Falcon sensor installed
choices.C: The Mac Sensor report displays a listing of all Mac hosts with a Falcon sensor installed

questions.question_text: Which of the following best describes the purpose of the Mac Sensor report?

discussion.content:
Answer D
D. A cumulative score of the various potential command line switches
Actually I am for the C here. https://www.crowdstrike.com/blog/tech-center/powershell-hunting/ Listen to what they say about the score field at around the end. Looks more logical to me.

comments.content: But it doesn't use NGAV to do that. Trick answer. The correct answer is D. Different CLI switches have different ratings ergo different scores. This is in the documentation.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
Checked falcon console, appears to be D

Selected Answer: D
this one seems most likely and couldnt find info on the other choices

choices.A: Number of hosts that ran the PowerShell script
choices.B: How recently the PowerShell script executed
choices.D: A cumulative score of the various potential command line switches

questions.question_text: In the Powershell Hunt report, what does the “score” signify?

choices.C: Highlights “badstring” in all command lines in the output
choices.A: Prevents command lines containing “badstring” from being displayed
choices.D: Highlights only the command lines containing “badstring”
choices.B: Displays only the command lines containing “badstring”

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Answer A
A. Prevents command lines containing “badstring” from being displayed 

Because !=, this is not include

questions.question_text: In the Powershell Hunt report, what does the filtering condition of CommandLine!="*badstring*" do?
